Inflation and Labor Market

Despite rising private housing rents, domestic cost pressures remained largely controlled, and external price pressures eased gradually, resulting in mild inflation in 2024 (see Chart 2). For the full year, core and overall inflation rates stood at 1.1% and 1.7%, respectively. 

The labor market maintained resilience in 2024, with the unemployment rate remaining low at between 2.9% and 3.1% (see Chart 3). From the first quarter onwards, total employment gradually increased, and the labor force also grew, reflecting stable labor demand and supply. Meanwhile, nominal wages and income for workers grew steadily in tandem with economic growth. The government announced further enhancements to Hong Kong’s Talent Attraction Scheme in the 2024 Policy Address, aiming to alleviate staff shortages across various industries and injecting new momentum into the local population by attracting more young people.

Chart 2 Core Consumer Price Inflation
Source: Census and Statistics Department

Chart 3 Labor Market Conditions
Source: Census and Statistics Department

Stock Market

Following a substantial rally since mid-September, Hong Kong’s stock market shifted notably in 2024. Specifically, with the Federal Reserve’s interest rate cuts and proactive economic stimulus measures introduced by China, market sentiment improved significantly, pushing the Hang Seng Index to the year's high of 23,100 points on October 7 (see Chart 4). However, concerns over the global economic outlook and the pace of monetary easing triggered a slight correction in the Hong Kong stock market in early November during the US Presidential Election. Despite this, the Hang Seng Index closed the year at 20,060 points, a substantial increase of 17.7% from the end of 2023, ending a four-year decline streak.

Property Market

The residential property market was generally weak in the first three quarters of 2024 but showed signs of stabilization in the fourth quarter. Policies easing in late February and mid-October, along with the support from the rate-cutting cycle that began in September, led to a significant 23.5% increase in the full-year residential transactions from the historic low of 43,002 units in 2023 to 53,099 units in 2024. Nonetheless, persistent high mortgage rates and accumulated inventories in the primary market continued to exert downward pressure on property prices. As a result, residential prices declined by 7.1% year-on-year in 2024, slightly improving housing affordability, although it remained relatively tight. The non-residential sector remained weak, with high vacancy rates in office space amid ample supply, while retail outlets faced challenges due to changing visitor and local consumer behaviors.

Economic Outlook

Economic Environment

Given the ongoing escalation of trade tensions, which are likely to disrupt international trade and capital flows, Hong Kong’s economy in 2025 is projected to face a challenging external environment. Nevertheless, continued support from relevant authorities and the banking sector should enhance local enterprises’ resilience. Mainland China’s proactive economic stimulus measures and breakthroughs in frontier technology sectors are also expected to bolster business confidence. Meanwhile, Hong Kong will further deepen regional cooperation and accelerate engagement with emerging markets. Additionally, with inbound tourism policies from Mainland China and government efforts to boost Hong Kong’s tourism industry, visitor arrivals are expected to further grow.

Inflation and Labor Market

Inflation in Hong Kong is forecasted to remain moderate in 2025. The gradual transfer of higher housing rents into consumer prices may exert slight upward pressure on local costs. Despite increased global economic uncertainties, external price pressures should stay mild. Conversely, the labor market might face challenges due to rising trade tensions. However, various talent attraction programs are expected to continue expanding a high-quality talent pool, supporting long-term economic development.

Banking System Performance

Hong Kong’s banking sector is expected to remain resilient in 2025, with ample capital and liquidity. While macroeconomic challenges may increase credit risks, overall asset quality remains manageable. Benefiting from higher gains on trading assets and increased fee and commission income, retail banking profits are projected to improve compared to 2024.

Asset Quality

The ratio of classified loans in the banking sector rose from 1.57% at the end of 2023 to 1.96% at the end of 2024. The non-performing and restructured loan ratio increased from 1.24% to 1.55% over the same period (see Chart 5). The rise in classified loans mainly reflects downgrades of certain Mainland real estate developers and local SME borrowers. However, the classified loan ratio for loans related to Mainland China decreased from 2.58% at the end of 2023 to 2.38% at the end of 2024. Banks maintained adequate provisions. As of the end of 2024, the loan loss reserve coverage, measured by the ratio of loan loss provisions and classified loans, was approximately 65%. After deducting collateral recoveries from bad debts, the adjusted loan loss reserve coverage was about 145%. Meanwhile, delinquency rates for residential mortgages and credit cards remained low at 0.11% and 0.35%, respectively (see Charts 6).

Source: Hong Kong Monetary Authority

Chart 6 Delinquency Ratios for Residential Mortgages and Credit Cards
Source: Hong Kong Monetary Authority

Profitability Trends

Retail banks’ pre-tax operating profit increased by 8.4% in 2024, and the return on average assets after tax rose from 0.88% to 0.93% (see Chart 7). The profit growth was mainly driven by a 97.0% surge in investment gains from trading assets and a 15.4% increase in fee and commission income, partially offset by a 5.2% decline in net interest income. The net interest margin contracted from 1.67% in 2023 to 1.52% in 2024 (see Chart 8). Meanwhile, the cost-to-income ratio slightly increased from 38.9% in 2023 to 39.2% in 2024 (see Chart 9).

Chart 7 Retail Banking Performance
Source: Hong Kong Monetary Authority

Chart 8 Net Interest Margin of Retail Banks
Source: Hong Kong Monetary Authority

Chart 9 Cost-Income Ratio of Retail Banks
Source: Hong Kong Monetary Authority

Balance Sheet Trends

The banking sector’s total assets and liabilities expanded by 4.3% in 2024, mainly due to a 13.4% increase in transferable debt securities. Lenders faced subdued demand amid high borrowing costs, with total loans decreasing by 2.8%. Loans used within Hong Kong fell by 2.1%, while offshore loans decreased by 5.7%. Trade finance, however, increased by 4.6%. Loans related to Mainland China declined by 8.7%. Deposits rose by 7.1% in 2024, higher than the 5.1% increase in 2023. Due to the reduction in total loans and the increase in deposits, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio decreased from 62.8% at the end of 2023 to 57.0% at the end of 2024 (see Chart 10).

Capital Adequacy Level

The banking sector maintained ample capital buffers in 2024. The comprehensive capital adequacy ratio of licensed financial institutions stood at 21.8% at year-end, up from 21.1% in the previous year; the Tier 1 capital ratio was 19.9% (see Chart 11). Both ratios far exceeded international minimum requirements. The Basel III leverage ratio at the end of 2024 was 8.0% (see Chart 12).

Liquidity Conditions

Liquidity in the banking sector remained stable. The average quarterly liquidity coverage ratio of Class 1 institutions in Q4 2024 was 178.4%, while the core funding ratio of Class 2 institutions averaged 67.0% (see Chart 13). Main funding sources for banks are still customer deposits. By the end of 2024, the net stable funding ratio of Class 1 institutions and the core funding ratio of Class 2A institutions were 143.4% and 186.7%, respectively (see Chart 14). All four ratios are well above statutory minimum requirements.

# 貨幣穩定

儘管美國貨幣政策走向、環球增長前景及地緣政治局勢緊張存在不明朗因素港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持暢順有序。港元匯率在2024年首四個月回軟，然後在年內其餘時間轉強。在聯繫匯率制度下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率的走勢，同時亦受本地供求情況影響。作為香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，聯繫匯率制度一直展現強大抵禦外來衝擊的能力。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：

- 負債證明書（為三間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）；
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣；
- 設於金管局的結算戶口結餘總額（即總結餘）；及
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。當強方（或弱方）兌換保證被觸發，金管局會應銀行要求，按每美元兌7.75港元向銀行沽出港元、買入美元（或按7.85港元買入港元、沽出美元），使總結餘增加（或減少），令港元利率下跌（或上升），從而促使港元匯率回復到7.75至7.85的兌換範圍。

# 2024年回顧

# 匯率穩定

在2024年首四個月，港元隨着流動性回軟而稍為轉弱。在4月下旬至5月中期間，主要在股息相關資金需求及股票市場交投活躍的支持下，港元匯率轉強。在8月初，由於市場一度憂慮美國經濟可能出現衰退，以及預期美國聯邦儲備局將以更快及更大幅度減息，觸發套息交易平倉及港元短倉平倉，使港元轉強至兌換保證範圍的強方。港元在9月下旬進一步走強，受惠於內地公布一系列經濟刺激措施後，本港股市交投急增。港元其後於11月初稍為轉弱，部分由於本港股市的升幅有所回落，部分則由於其時美國經濟表現強勁，給予聯邦公開市場委員會空間謹慎地調低聯邦基金利率所致。其後港元在年底季節性資金需求帶動下回升。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2024年全年繼續運作正常（圖1）。

圖 1 2024年市場匯率

由於年內並無觸發兌換保證，總結餘變動不大，維持在447億港元左右。與此同時，未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由12,455億港元，稍增至13,839億港元。因此，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由2023 年底的 12,904 億港元，增加至 2024 年底的 14,287億港元（圖2）。整體貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

圖 2 2024年總結餘（進行貼現窗活動前）及未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣市場

在聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率走勢，當中短期拆息亦受本地供求情況影響。隨着市場對美國政策利率下調的預期逐漸升溫，香港銀行同業拆息在2024年首八個月大致回軟（圖3）。在季末季節性資金需求及股市交投活躍的推動下，香港銀行同業拆息於9月下旬收緊，隔夜拆息於季末更一度升至6厘以上。其後香港銀行同業拆息大致穩定，至年底前因流動性相對減少而上升。全年計，隔夜、一個月及三個月香港銀行同業拆息分別下跌45、69及78基點至年底時的5.65厘、4.58厘及4.37厘。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標區間下調，基本利率下調三次，合共一個百分點（即100基點），由5.75厘下跌至4.75厘（圖3）。在零售層面，隨着美國下調政策利率，多間銀行在9月中調低最優惠貸款利率25基點，並在11月初及12月下旬分別再調低25基點及12.5基點。在此情況下，新造按揭貸款平均利率亦由2023年的4.13厘下跌至2024年12月的3.59厘。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2023年的388億港元增至2024年的500億港元；貼現窗的使用情況未見異常。

圖 3 2024年香港銀行同業拆息

# 聯繫匯率制度

自1983年以來，聯匯制度一直是香港金融體系的重要支柱，展現強大應對挑戰的能力。儘管美國政策利率走向存在不確定因素，以及地緣經濟碎片化，港元外匯及貨幣市場維持有序運作，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在《2024年對外部門報告》一再重申香港擁有具透明度的規則、龐大的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融規管與監管、靈活的經濟，以及審慎的財政架構，確保聯匯制度具公信力。

穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用。香港銀行體系繼續運作暢順，流動性及資本狀況以國際標準而言均非常充裕。為確保銀行體系具備抵禦衝擊的能力，金管局一直密切監察銀行的信用、流動性與利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行貸款的監管。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）由2023年底的110.73%上升至2024年9月10日的112.65%高位，超出112.5%的觸發上限（圖4），當中主要來自投資的利息及投資按市價重估。按照外匯基金諮詢委員會批准的安排，從支持組合轉撥資產至投資組合，令支持比率於9月11日降至110.08%左右。其後支持比率大致保持穩定，於12月31日收報109.56%。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，加上香港穩健的銀行體系，為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強而有力的後盾。

# Monetary Stability

Despite uncertainties surrounding the US monetary policy outlook, global growth prospects, and geopolitical tensions, Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange and currency markets continued to operate smoothly and orderly. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate softened in the first four months of 2024, then strengthened for the remainder of the year. Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong banks’ interbank interest rates largely followed US interest rate trends, while also being influenced by local supply and demand. As the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated strong resilience against external shocks.

# Objectives

Hong Kong's monetary policy's main objective is to maintain currency stability, ensuring that the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remains within the range of 7.75 to 7.85 HKD per USD on the foreign exchange market. The currency system mainly adopts the Currency Board System, which stipulates that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund must provide at least 100% support to the monetary base; if the monetary base changes, USD reserves must be adjusted accordingly, maintaining a 100% match with movements in the monetary base.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:

- Certificates of indebtedness (fully backing banknotes issued by three note-issuing banks);
- Circulating banknotes and coins issued by the government;
- Total balance of settlement accounts with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HAM); and
- Exchange Fund bills and bonds issued by the government on behalf of the Hong Kong Government.

Table 1 Monetary Base

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains currency stability through an automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and a firm commitment to exchange guarantees. When a strong-side (or weak-side) exchange guarantee is triggered, the HKMA will, upon banks’ request, sell HKD and buy USD at 7.75 HKD/USD or buy HKD and sell USD at 7.85 HKD/USD, increasing (or decreasing) the total balance, which causes Hong Kong dollar interest rates to fall (or rise), helping the exchange rate return to the 7.75–7.85 range.

# 2024 Review

# Exchange Rate Stability

In the first four months of 2024, the Hong Kong dollar slightly weakened due to liquidity easing. Between late April and mid-May, supported by dividend-related fund demand and active stock market trading, the HKD exchange rate strengthened. In early August, due to market concerns over a potential recession in the US economy and expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut rates more rapidly and by larger margins, carry trade unwinding and short HKD positions led to the HKD strengthening to the guarantee range’s strong side. In late September, the HKD further appreciated, buoyed by the Mainland’s announcement of a series of economic stimulus measures and a sharp increase in local stock market activity. Subsequently, in early November, the HKD slightly weakened, partly due to a retreat in the stock market gains and partly because the US economic performance was strong, giving the Federal Open Market Committee room to cautiously lower the federal funds rate. Later, the HKD rose again into the year-end driven by seasonal liquidity demand. Overall, the foreign exchange market in 2024 continued to operate normally (Figure 1).

Figure 1 Market exchange rates in 2024

Since no exchange guarantees were triggered during the year, total balances remained relatively stable at around HKD 44.7 billion. Meanwhile, the total outstanding of Exchange Fund bills and bonds increased slightly from HKD 1,245.5 billion to HKD 1,383.9 billion. As a result, total balances plus outstanding bills and bonds rose from HKD 1,290.4 billion at the end of 2023 to HKD 1,428.7 billion at the end of 2024 (Figure 2). The overall monetary base remains fully backed by foreign exchange reserves.

Figure 2 Total balances and outstanding Exchange Fund bills and bonds in 2024 (before discount window activities)

# Money Market

Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong banks’ interbank interest rates generally followed US interest rate trends, with short-term rates also affected by local supply and demand. As expectations for US policy rate cuts gradually increased, Hong Kong interbank rates largely eased during the first eight months of 2024 (Figure 3). Supported by seasonal fund demand and active stock trading at quarter-end, interbank rates tightened in late September, with overnight rates rising above 6%. Afterwards, rates remained roughly stable, then rose again before year-end as liquidity decreased. Over the year, the overnight, 1-month, and 3-month Hong Kong interbank rates fell by 45, 69, and 78 basis points, respectively, reaching 5.65%, 4.58%, and 4.37% by year’s end.

In response to the US federal funds rate target range reduction, the basic rate was cut three times, totaling 100 basis points, from 5.75% to 4.75% (Figure 3). At the retail level, as US policy rates declined, several banks reduced their best lending rates by 25 basis points in mid-September, and further by 25 basis points in early November and by 12.5 basis points in late December. Consequently, the average new mortgage lending rate declined from 4.13% in 2023 to 3.59% in December 2024. Overall, Hong Kong’s money market continued to function normally. Discount window lending rose from HKD 38.8 billion in 2023 to HKD 50 billion in 2024; usage of the discount window remained normal.

Figure 3 Hong Kong interbank interest rates in 2024

# Linked Exchange Rate System

Since 1983, the linked exchange rate system has been a vital pillar of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating strong resilience against challenges. Despite uncertainties in US policy rate trends and geopolitical economic fragmentation, Hong Kong’s foreign exchange and monetary markets remained orderly, reflecting the robustness and effectiveness of the linked system. The government remains committed to maintaining the linked exchange rate system. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) repeatedly reaffirmed in the 2024 External Sector Report that Hong Kong possesses transparent rules, substantial fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, sound financial regulation and supervision, economic flexibility, and prudent fiscal architecture, all of which underpin the credibility of the system.

A robust banking sector is crucial to the orderly operation of the linked system. Hong Kong’s banking sector continues to operate smoothly, with liquidity and capital positions both highly ample by international standards. To ensure resilience against shocks, the HKMA actively monitors banks’ credit, liquidity, and interest rate risks, as well as stress test results, and maintains prudent banking supervision.

To enhance transparency of the Monetary Authority’s accounts, since October 1998, part of the Exchange Fund’s assets have been designated to support the monetary base. The support ratio (the proportion of supporting assets relative to the monetary base) rose from 110.73% at the end of 2023 to a high of 112.65% on September 10, 2024, exceeding the trigger threshold of 112.5% (Figure 4), mainly due to interest income and revaluation of investments at market value. Following approval by the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, assets were reallocated from the support portfolio to the investment portfolio, causing the support ratio to decline to approximately 110.08% on September 11. Since then, the ratio has generally stabilized, closing at 109.56% on December 31. Under the linked exchange rate system, although certain assets are designated as part of the support portfolio, all Exchange Fund assets can be used to support the HKD exchange rate. The large fiscal resources of the Exchange Fund, together with Hong Kong’s resilient banking sector, provide a strong backing for currency and financial stability.

The Currency Issue Committee, under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, oversees and discusses issues related to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability. In 2024, topics included risk exposures of Hong Kong banks to non-bank financial institutions and the implementation frameworks of major advanced economies’ monetary policies. Meeting minutes and the Monetary Authority’s report on the operation of the Currency Issue System are available on the HKMA website.

# 銀行體系穩定

儘管面對宏觀經濟挑戰及地緣政治的不確定性，香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健。金管局迅速採取措施支援本地中小型企業，並透過風險為本監管與應變規劃保障銀行體系穩定，另又提供監管指引及支持業界應對新生風險，以提升銀行業的運作穩健性與網絡防衛韌性。為鼓勵應用金融科技，金管局推出連串跨行業項目，包括生成式人工智能「沙盒」。

金管局推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》，以加強銀行消費者保障。我們又推出「智安存」協助存款人有效保護存款，以及有關銀行無抵押消費信貸產品的冷靜期以減低衝動及過度借貸的風險。此外，金管局向銀行提供有關在面向客戶的服務中應用生成式人工智能的指引，又就二手物業買賣交易提供多一種支付安排與業界緊密合作。金管局亦透過發出數碼資產相關活動的指引、優化「跨境理財通」業務試點，以及簡化銷售投資及保險產品程序，提升客戶體驗，並同時確保投資者保障。年內完成個人信貸資料服務全面過渡至「信資通」。

金管局在香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度方面扮演重要角色。透過提高經由反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組交換情報的速度及數量，與2023年相比，情報主導的可疑交易報告增加303%，促使凍結或充公的犯罪得益增加34%。有關促進銀行分享訊息以協助偵測及防止金融罪行的法例修訂的諮詢得到廣泛支持。金管局在4月根據交易監察系統專題審查結果提供指引，以及在9月推出計劃促進業界應用人工智能監察可疑活動。金管局亦與銀行業及香港警務處合作，優化「可疑帳號警示」機制及加強宣傳工作，並就防範、偵測及制止授權支付詐騙向銀行發出指引。

香港在實施包括資本充足及披露等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。香港存款保障委員會優化了存款保障計劃的多個範疇，以加強對存款人的保障。

為確保處置機制具公信力，金管局實施處置標準，規定銀行須更新與對手方的金融合約，減低處置中的提前終止風險。此外，金管局在制定銀行的首選處置策略、應對處置可行性障礙以確保有足夠財政資源及處置中的運作持續性，以及提升處置執行能力方面均取得顯著進展。

# 目標

金管局的目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因其營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響金融體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊及應對危機，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。

香港的審慎監管制度並非為確保「零風險」而設。事實上，作為一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，我們有必要制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

金融管理專員亦負責指定及監察某些金融市場基建。金管局監察金融市場基建的目的，是促進有關基建的整體安全及效率、減低系統性風險，以及提高透明度。提升金融市場基建面對金融危機的抗震能力，能保障香港的貨幣與金融體系，避免因金融市場基建運作中斷而影響其穩定。

# 2024年回顧

# 牌照事宜

年內金管局向一間在香港成立為法團的銀行及一間在香港以外成立為法團的銀行授予銀行牌照。金管局亦核准一間在香港以外的交易商經紀成為貨幣經紀。此外，年內金管局撤銷三間持牌銀行、一間有限制牌照銀行及一間接受存款公司的認可資格。

有關香港的認可機構及本地代表辦事處的更多資訊，請參閱分別載於第311至314頁及第320至323頁的附錄及表D至F。

# 檢討銀行三級制

在2024年，金管局完成有關簡化銀行三級制至二級制的公眾諮詢，回應者普遍支持簡化建議。經考慮所收到的意見，金管局就建議提出若干新的關鍵事項，以精簡過渡過程及減少對接受存款公司現有客戶的影響。

# 「虛擬銀行」易名

此外，金管局完成有關「虛擬銀行(Virtual Bank)」易名為「數字銀行(Digital Bank)」的公眾諮詢。易名建議得到廣泛支持，金管局遂於10月修訂法定指引《數字銀行的認可》，有關建議正式生效。

# 數字銀行的檢討

在2024年完成的另一項工作是全面檢討數字銀行，檢討報告已於8月發表。有關檢討顯示數字銀行發展至今已達到在香港引入數字銀行的三項政策目標，即推動金融科技與創新、提供新的客戶體驗，以及促進普及金融。在數字銀行和傳統銀行的多樣化發展下，金管局認為現時數字銀行牌照的數量合適，現階段沒有必要在市場上引入更多新的數字銀行參與者。10月發出的修訂指引《數字銀行的認可》放寬了數項對業界的限制，包括容許數字銀行經營零售銀行業務以外的銀行業務，以及在從客戶體驗與業務策略的角度而言屬合理的情況下設立實體分行，前提是數字銀行繼續主要透過數碼渠道提供銀行服務。

# 銀行牌照費的檢討

金管局於年內完成對牌照費的檢討，並於6月提高費用水平。

# 香港的公司遷冊制度

金管局就於香港引入公司遷冊制度向政府提供支援，包括協助修訂《銀行業條例》及其附屬法例以及其他與金管局有關的法例的立法程序。

# 監管工作概覽

年內金管局共進行174次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍甚廣，包括認可機構的CAMEL評估、企業管治及風險管理。為繼續加強認可機構的風險管治水平，金管局與認可機構董事局、獨立非執行董事或董事局轄下委員會共舉行36次會議，並與認可機構及其外聘核數師共舉行38次三方聯席會議。此外，金管局對認可機構的各項業務進行現場審查，包括信用、市場及流動性風險管理方面的管治與做法。

# Banking System Stability

Despite facing macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical uncertainties, Hong Kong's banking system remained resilient in 2024. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) swiftly implemented measures to support local SMEs, and through risk-based regulation and contingency planning, it safeguarded the stability of the banking system. Additionally, the HKMA provided regulatory guidance and support for industry responses to emerging risks to enhance operational robustness and cyber resilience. To promote the application of financial technology, the HKMA launched a series of cross-sector projects, including a Generative Artificial Intelligence "Sandbox."

The HKMA introduced the "Protection of Consumers Against Fraudulent Activities Charter 2.0" to strengthen consumer protection. We also launched "Smart Safe Deposit" to help depositors effectively safeguard their deposits, alongside measures such as a cooling-off period for certain unsecured consumer credit products to reduce impulsive and over-leveraged borrowing. Furthermore, the HKMA issued guidelines on the application of generative artificial intelligence in customer-facing services, and provided an additional payment arrangement for second-hand property transactions in close cooperation with industry stakeholders. The HKMA also issued guidance related to digital asset activities, optimized the "Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect" pilot, and simplified procedures for selling investment and insurance products to improve customer experience while ensuring investor protection. Over the course of the year, the personal credit information service transitioned fully to the "Credit Data Interchange."

The HKMA plays an important role in Hong Kong’s anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing system. By enhancing the speed and volume of information exchange within anti-scam and anti-money laundering information-sharing workgroups, suspicious transaction reports led by intelligence increased by 303% compared to 2023, resulting in a 34% rise in frozen or confiscated criminal proceeds. Broad support was received for consultations on amendments to legislation facilitating banks to share information to assist in detecting and preventing financial crimes. Based on findings from the transaction monitoring system review in April, the HKMA issued guidelines and, in September, launched initiatives to promote industry use of artificial intelligence to monitor suspicious activities. The HKMA also partnered with banks and the Hong Kong Police Force to optimize the "Suspicious Account Alerts" mechanism and enhance publicity efforts, including issuing guidance on preventing authorized payment scams.

Hong Kong made good progress in implementing international prudential standards including capital adequacy and disclosure. The Deposit Protection Scheme (DPS) has also been optimized across multiple areas to further strengthen depositor protection.

To ensure the credibility of resolution mechanisms, the HKMA implemented resolution standards requiring banks to update their financial contracts with counterparties to reduce early termination risks. The HKMA made notable progress in developing preferred resolution strategies, addressing obstacles to resolution feasibility with sufficient financial resources, and strengthening operational capabilities for resolving near-failure authorized institutions. To effectively execute these tasks, the HKMA adopts a nationally consistent and coordinated approach.

The HKMA is also responsible for designating and overseeing certain market infrastructure. The purpose of supervising financial market infrastructure is to promote overall safety and efficiency, reduce systemic risk, and enhance transparency. Strengthening the resilience of financial market infrastructure against financial crises helps safeguard Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, preventing operational disruptions from affecting stability.

# 2024 Review

# Licensing Matters

Within the year, the HKMA granted banking licenses to one bank incorporated in Hong Kong and one bank incorporated outside Hong Kong. It also approved a merchant bank outside Hong Kong to become a currency broker. Additionally, the HKMA revoked the authorized status of three licensed banks, one restricted license bank, and one deposit-taking company.

For more information on authorized institutions and local representative offices in Hong Kong, please refer to the appendices on pages 311–314, 320–323, and Tables D–F.

# Review of the Third-Level Banking System

In 2024, the HKMA completed a public consultation on simplifying the banking third-tier system to a two-tier system. The feedback was broadly supportive of the proposed simplification. After considering comments received, the HKMA put forward several new key points to streamline the transition process and minimize impact on existing customers of deposit-taking companies.

# Renaming of "Virtual Banks"

Furthermore, the HKMA completed a public consultation on renaming "Virtual Banks" as "Digital Banks." The proposal was widely supported, and in October, the HKMA amended the statutory guidelines "Authorization of Digital Banks," with the changes coming into effect formally.

# Review of Digital Banks

Another key work completed in 2024 was a comprehensive review of digital banks, with the report published in August. The review showed that digital banks have now met three policy objectives in Hong Kong: promoting fintech and innovation, providing new customer experiences, and advancing financial inclusion. Given the diversified development of both digital and traditional banks, the HKMA considers the current number of digital banking licenses appropriate and saw no need to introduce additional new digital bank participants into the market at this stage. The revised guidelines "Authorization of Digital Banks," issued in October, relaxed several industry restrictions, including allowing digital banks to operate beyond retail banking and establishing physical branches under reasonable circumstances from a customer experience and business strategy perspective, provided that digital banks continue primarily to deliver banking services via digital channels.

# Review of Banking License Fees

The HKMA completed a review of licensing fees within the year and increased fee levels in June.

# Hong Kong’s Company Migration System

The HKMA supported the government’s introduction of a company migration system in Hong Kong, including assisting in legislative amendments to the Banking Ordinance and its subsidiary legislation, as well as other relevant laws.

# Overview of Supervisory Work

During the year, the HKMA conducted a total of 174 off-site reviews, covering a broad range of areas including CAMEL assessments, corporate governance, and risk management of authorized institutions. To further strengthen risk governance, the HKMA held 36 meetings with the boards of authorized institutions, independent non-executive directors, and committees under boards, and 38 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors. The HKMA also conducted on-site examinations of authorized institutions’ business operations, including governance and practices related to credit, market, and liquidity risk management.

As technology adoption by authorized institutions becomes more widespread, operational and technological risk management has become another regulatory重点。 The HKMA further enhanced supervision of climate risk management to improve institutions’ capacity to respond to climate change. The HKMA’s efforts to maintain financial stability and promote steady economic growth amidst global economic uncertainties have been recognized, earning the AsianBanker magazine’s “Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific" award.

Deputy Chief Executive (Banking Supervision) Ms. Julia Chui (center) accepted the "Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific" award from AsianBanker magazine on behalf of the HKMA.

In terms of conduct regulation, the HKMA conducts onsite reviews of authorized institutions’ securities, investment products, trusts, insurance, statutory provident fund (MPF) related activities, and consumer protection issues. The HKMA also includes thematic assessments to examine new products or areas deemed higher risk.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局於2024年在加強香港作為具全球競爭力的國際金融中心的地位方面取得重要進展。

金管局與內地及香港有關當局合作，推出一系列措施，共同深化及擴展香港與內地金融市場的互聯互通，包括優化「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」；擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排及「北向互換通」的合資格抵押品範圍；優化「北向互換通」；以及優化一級流動性提供行安排。這些措施有助強化香港的門戶角色，並鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位

金管局在鞏固香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、綠色和可持續金融，以及企業財資中心等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強面向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家充分認識香港金融體系的穩健及其帶來的機遇。第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及多項其他盛事成功舉辦，不僅有助提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的形象，更製造正面的漣漪效應。金管局積極參與多個國際及區內的央行及監管組織，繼續對維持金融穩定及促進金融市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

金管局在「金融科技2025」 策略的各個範疇均取得顯著進展，包括央行數碼貨幣及數據基建。

快速支付系統「轉數快」的登記數目及交易量繼續穩步增長，於2024年底達到1,580萬個登記，全年平均每日處理港元即時交易增至165萬宗。金管局正與中國人民銀行緊密合作，推動落實香港「轉數快」與內地網上支付跨行清算系統互聯，實現跨境支付。

# 概覽

在2024年，金管局繼續致力提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

金管局擴展及優化香港與內地間的互聯互通機制，有助鞏固香港作為內地與國際金融市場間的橋樑角色。年內，多項有關「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）的優化措施出台，便利粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）個人投資者進行跨境投資。於2月，金管局將中華人民共和國財政部（國家財政部）發行的在岸國債和內地政策性銀行發行的政策性金融債納入人民幣流動資金安排的合資格抵押品名單。於7月，兩地相關部門公布進一步支持境外投資者使用通過「債券通」持有的在岸債券作為「北向互換通」交易的履約抵押品，並於2025年1月實施。此外，「北向互換通」於年內進行優化，增加投資者在對沖策略和管理投資組合方面的靈活性及效率。

在2024年，香港的離岸人民幣業務穩健增長。金管局推出一級流動性提供行安排的優化措施，包括增加提供行數目及擴大安排規模。於年底前，香港人民幣即時支付結算系統的夜間跨境服務能力提升，以更好應付全球各地對跨境人民幣支付的需要。

金管局推出大灣區金融合作下的多項利民便商措施，包括促進企業跨境融資的跨境徵信互通業務試點，以及便利香港居民在大灣區置業的跨境匯款支付安排。

金管局繼續致力提升香港整體金融平台的競爭力。具體而言，為增強香港作為首選基金管理中心及家族辦公室業務樞紐的吸引力，金管局與政府及金融業緊密合作，締造更便利的稅務及監管環境。此外，金管局透過Evergreen項目發行第二批代幣化債券，並推出「EvergreenHub」一站式數碼債券知識庫和「數碼債券資助計劃」，繼續推動香港債券市場創新。於10月，金管局公布「可持續金融行動計劃」，訂明進一步鞏固香港作為區內綠色和可持續金融樞紐的具體目標。

另一方面，金管局繼續加強市場拓展工作，向海外及內地持份者介紹香港的金融服務。金管局在11月舉辦第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，主題為「在變局中前航」，雲集全球各地金融業界翹楚分享各自獨到的觀點。峰會先由國務院副總理何立峰先生作開幕主題演講，接着是三間內地金融監管機構的分享環節，以及由國際金融領袖參與的專題討論。峰會共匯聚350多位來自超過120間國際金融機構的領袖參與，充分體現國際金融界對香港的支持和信心。

年內金管局亦舉辦各項其他研討會及會議，包括：

- 於9月與迪拜金融服務管理局合辦聯合氣候金融會議；
- 於10月與全球風險管理專業人士協會合辦第15屆全球風險論壇；
- 於10月亦與國際結算銀行合辦國際金融研討會；及
- 於12月舉辦金融穩定理事會全體會議，是自2016年以來首次在亞洲舉行的同類會議，匯聚超過50個國家財政金融機關及12個國際標準制定機構的領袖和高級官員。

年內金管局亦積極加強與其他地區的雙邊聯繫。於12月，金管局分別與阿拉伯聯合酋長國中央銀行（阿聯酋央行）及沙特中央銀行（沙特央行）在香港舉行雙邊會議，促進中東與亞洲地區之間的投資及金融市場聯繫。金管局與阿聯酋央行簽署諒解備忘錄，建立兩地債務資本市場基建的互聯互通，並促進跨境債務證券發行及投資活動。在此之前，金管局於10月訪問卡塔爾多哈，加強兩地金融服務領域的合作。

此外，金管局於12月舉行第七次香港與瑞士金融合作對話，討論內容涵蓋區內及本地的前景與政策挑戰，以及可持續金融、金融科技與市場互聯互通領域的最新發展及潛在合作空間。

金管局分別於1月及5月訪問泰國和馬來西亞，與中央銀行、金融機構和企業會面，推廣香港作為國際金融中心的地位，並進一步加強雙邊金融聯繫和合作。重點領域之一是推廣使用人民幣和本地貨幣作跨境投資和貿易結算，以及香港的競爭優勢。

在國際層面，金管局積極參與中央銀行領域的事務，並繼續在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。金管局現為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組和金融穩定理事會轄下亞洲區域諮詢小組的聯席主席，另又擔任金融穩定理事會轄下金融創新網絡聯席主席（至2024年7月止）。金管局亦為國際結算銀行轄下主要新興市場經濟體行長會議和金融穩定理事會轄下加密資產框架同業評審小組的主席。在2018至2024年間，金管局一直連任東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室與各銀行部門繼續實施「金融科技2025」策略，促進業界廣泛採用金融科技，並提升香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位。年內推行的主要措施包括：

- 進一步推動銀行在五個主要範疇的金融科技應用，包括財富科技、保險科技、綠色科技、人工智能及分布式分類帳技術；
- 推動央行數碼貨幣的工作，以了解其效益及潛在的應用場景，包括：
    - 推進「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目，以改善跨境支付；
    - 進一步研究在香港發行「數碼港元」(e-HKD)的可行性；及

# 儲備管理

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。主要經濟體錄得穩定增長，而通脹亦回落至更接近政策目標的水平。多個主要央行陸續下調政策利率，有利投資環境。2024年全年計，外匯基金錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，投資回報率為5.2%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(i) 保障資本；
(ii) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(iii) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(iv) 在符合上述(i)至(iii)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障外匯基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合架構及目標資產配置中反映（圖示1）。

圖示1 外匯基金的投資組合類別

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員經濟體的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的目標資產配置與其他資產類別的配置，按審慎的風險管理原則及資產組合多元化策略一起制定。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子，其存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的回報掛鈎，利率視乎實際資產配置而定。於2024年，投資組合與長期增長組合在未來基金的目標資產配置約為35：65。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責外匯基金的投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約70%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分內部管理的投資組合包括環球定息市場投資，並透過不同的衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取外聘投資經理的市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，穩健的風險管理更見重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線，以實施有效的風險管理及管治。金管局定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並設置風險管理程序，為策略性規劃及多元化投資工作提供穩健的框架。

# 負責任投資

金管局相信適度強調負責任投資及投資的可持續長期表現，可更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動涉及的環境、社會及管治(ESG)相關風險。為積極支持負責任投資，金管局已將ESG因素融入外匯基金的投資管理過程中，其指導性原則是：當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。有關金管局在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見《二零二四年可持續發展報告》之「負責任投資」一章。

The performance of the global financial markets in 2024 was generally positive. Major economies recorded stable growth, and inflation also retreated closer to policy targets. Several key central banks consecutively lowered policy interest rates, creating favorable investment environments. For the full year of 2024, the Exchange Fund achieved investment income of HKD 218.8 billion, with an investment return rate of 5.2%.

Foreign Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to influence the Hong Kong dollar's exchange rate directly or indirectly, and it can also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system, thereby safeguarding Hong Kong’s status as an international financial center. The HKMA, under powers delegated by the Financial Secretary and provisions of the delegation, is responsible for the utilization and investment management of the Exchange Fund.

Management of the Exchange Fund

Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee sets the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:

(i) to safeguard capital;
(ii) to ensure that the overall monetary base is always fully supported by highly liquid US dollar assets;
(iii) to ensure liquidity is sufficient to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(iv) to pursue, within the framework of (i) to (iii), investment returns to protect the long-term purchasing power of the Exchange Fund.

These objectives comprehensively reflect the statutory purpose of the Exchange Fund and are incorporated into its portfolio structure and target asset allocation (see Diagram 1).

Diagram 1: Asset Classes of the Exchange Fund Investment Portfolio

Generally, the Exchange Fund’s portfolio divides into two main parts: support portfolio and investment portfolio. The support portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets, providing full support to the monetary base in accordance with currency issuance regulations. The investment portfolio primarily invests in debt and equity markets of economies that are members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), ensuring asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance medium- to long-term returns, the HKMA, following prudent and gradual principles, diversifies some assets of the Exchange Fund into more asset classes, including emerging markets, onshore bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging markets and onshore bonds and equities are held within the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held within the long-term growth portfolio. The target asset allocations of the long-term growth portfolio are crafted based on prudent risk management principles and diversification strategies.

A strategic asset allocation was established in 2007, mainly holding Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited shares purchased for strategic purposes. Due to its unique nature, the performance of this portfolio is not included in the overall investment evaluation of the Exchange Fund.

Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund periodically accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations. The interest rates are generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolios. Future deposits mainly represent individual cases, with their interest rates tied to returns from the investment and long-term growth portfolios, depending on actual asset allocations. By 2024, the ratio of the investment portfolio to the long-term growth portfolio for future assets was approximately 35:65.

Investment Procedures

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on strategic and tactical asset allocations. Strategic asset allocation reflects the long-term asset mix aimed at achieving investment objectives, serving as a reference for long-term asset distribution. The Fund adopts strategic allocation as a guideline, and through tactical adjustments, aims to achieve returns exceeding benchmarks. Actual allocations often deviate from the benchmark (strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocation is called “strategic deviation.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmarks and tracking error limits, with the HKMA authorized to determine the strategic asset allocation and permissible ranges for strategic deviation. Portfolio managers manage positions within these tolerances to capitalize on short-term market variations.

Direct Investment

The HKMA's Exchange Fund Investment Office is responsible for direct investment and related risk management functions. Staff in this office manage approximately 70% of the investments directly, including the entire support portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. Investments managed internally include global fixed-income markets and macro risk management strategies using various derivatives.

External Investment Managers

Apart from internal staff managing assets, the HKMA also hires external investment managers responsible for about 30% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other specialized asset categories. External managers are employed to leverage market-leading expertise, aiming to generate sustainable returns, benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, and gain market insights and specialized knowledge from these managers.

Expenses related to external managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes, which vary annually depending on market conditions.

Risk Management and Oversight

In increasingly complex investment environments, robust risk management is vital. The HKMA imposes strict controls and investment guidelines on internally managed and externally managed portfolios, and establishes rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. A three-tier defense is implemented across investment activities to ensure effective risk governance. The HKMA regularly monitors major investment risk categories, including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks, and establishes risk management procedures to support strategic planning and diversification efforts within a sound framework.

Responsible Investment

The HKMA believes that emphasizing responsible investment and sustainable long-term performance can more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the Exchange Fund while reducing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) related risks. To actively promote responsible investment, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into the investment management process of the Exchange Fund. The guiding principle is: when ESG investments have comparable long-term risk-adjusted returns to other investments, ESG investments are generally given priority. Details of the HKMA’s work in responsible investment can be found in the Chapter on “Responsible Investment” in the 2024 Sustainable Development Report.

Performance of the Exchange Fund

2024 Financial Market Overview

The global financial markets in 2024 performed generally well.

Main equity markets saw significant gains, with the US stock market making notable advances in the first three quarters amid favorable economic and inflation outlooks and a booming artificial intelligence sector. However, in the fourth quarter, market conditions became volatile due to concerns over rising inflation and rising bond yields, leading to a retreat from highs and increased investor caution. Domestic and Hong Kong stock markets benefited from a series of economic-stimulating and market-supportive policies introduced by the central authorities in the third quarter, improving investor confidence. Nonetheless, given ongoing uncertainties in the real economy’s growth prospects, the markets softened in the fourth quarter.

The global bond market also experienced considerable volatility in 2024. Despite the broad direction of major central banks towards easing monetary policy, the pace and extent of rate cuts frequently changed throughout the year. In the fourth quarter, attention shifted toward US fiscal policy for 2025, with US bond yields rising sharply and bond prices coming under pressure.

In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened against major currencies in 2024, especially in the fourth quarter, driven by relatively strong US economic performance and interest rate movements.

# Institutional Functions

The institutional functions department supports the operations of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, maintains high transparency and accountability, and demonstrates excellent efficiency and professionalism. To promote public understanding of the policies and work of the HKMA, the organization actively engages with the broader society and market participants through traditional and social media, the HKMA website, the HKMA Information Centre, and other channels.

Internally, the HKMA is committed to developing a flexible, professional workforce, strictly adhering to fiscal discipline, and enhancing digital capabilities to adapt to change and ensure effective implementation of policies and initiatives.

# Maintaining Transparency

# Media Relations and Social Media Applications

The HKMA maintains close ties with the media to enhance transparency and deepen public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2024, the HKMA organized or participated in 207 events, including 14 press conferences, four media briefings, 14 on-site interviews, and 175 other public activities. To raise awareness of its key functions, the HKMA held press conferences and media briefings for local, Mainland, and overseas media covering topics such as tokenization, fraud prevention measures, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises. Throughout the year, the HKMA also arranged 25 media interviews, issued approximately 600 bilingual press releases, and handled numerous daily media inquiries.

Mr. Yu Weiwen, the Chief Executive, participated in a live media interview at the Hong Kong Fintech Week 2024.

Mr. Lee Tak Chi, Vice President, delivered welcome remarks at the "Account Openings" case showcase.

Media representatives actively participated in HKMA-hosted events in 2024, especially the third "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit." The three-day summit attracted over ten thousand news reports from local, Mainland, and international media.

Mr. Yu Weiwen, the Chief Executive, was interviewed via live broadcast during the "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit 2024."

Mr. Ruan Guoheng, Vice President, hosted a media briefing on the establishment of the "SME Financing Task Force."

Mr. Chen Weimin, Vice President, delivered the opening speech at the "2024 Financial Markets Summit."

To connect more effectively with the public, the HKMA operates six social media pages (including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, WeChat, X (formerly Twitter), and YouTube), which have attracted over 200,000 followers. Creative social media content enhances public awareness of issues and initiatives such as fraud prevention, Fintech, green and sustainable finance, support for SMEs, and major HKMA events. The HKMA also livestreamed the "International Financial Leaders Investment Summit" via its social media pages to facilitate community and industry participation.

Publishing innovative content on social media helps increase public awareness of HKMA initiatives and various issues.

# Public Inquiries

The HKMA’s public inquiry service provides an effective channel for citizens to better understand its core functions and operations.

In 2024, the service processed 9,594 inquiries (see Chart 1), all responded to within the HKMA’s service commitments (Table 1). About half of these inquiries related to banking consumer matters, financial infrastructure and bond market development, banking policies and regulations, as well as banknotes and coins (see Fig. 2). Common inquiries include coin collection schemes, banking products and services, retail bond issuance plans, banking-related guidelines and notices, and the Faster Payment System.

# Publications

During the year, the HKMA published the "2023 Annual Report" and the "2023 Sustainable Development Report." The latter received a Recom­mendation Award in the "Public/Non-Profit (Large)" category at the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants’ "Best Corporate Governance and ESG Awards 2024." The "2023 Annual Report" was also awarded the Bronze Award in the "Non-Profit and Charitable Organizations" category at the Hong Kong Institute of Management Consultants' Best Annual Report Competition 2024.

In 2024, the HKMA regularly updates the "Financial Data Monthly" Data Set, and published:

- Two semiannual reports on "Money and Financial Stability";
- Four quarterly reports; and
- 14 articles in the "HKMA Insight" series.

# Organization Website

The HKMA website (www.hkma.gov.hk) contains over 73,000 pages of information in English and Chinese (Traditional and Simplified), providing the public with easy access to the latest information. The site also hosts the "Recognized Institutions and Local Representative Office Records" and "Recognized Institutions Securities Staff Records" maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Stored Value Facility Licensees Records" under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance.

Since 2018, the HKMA has adopted open application programming interfaces (APIs), releasing financial data and key information via its website in phases. By the end of 2024, a total of 177 sets of APIs had been launched, following the original plan. For more details on the HKMA’s open APIs, please visit the HKMA Open API Portal (https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk).

# Information Centre

The HKMA Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of the International Finance Centre Phase 2. It is divided into an exhibition hall and a library, aiming to introduce the HKMA’s work to the public and enhance understanding of monetary and banking matters. The exhibition hall presents interactive displays about the HKMA’s functions, the development of Hong Kong’s currency and banking industry, along with related materials and exhibits for research purposes.

In the year, the Centre welcomed over 68,000 visitors, an increase of about 120% compared to 2023. The Centre also conducts over 570 guided tours for schools and other groups.

The adjacent library holds over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications on topics related to Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. It also offers the "Recognized Institutions and Local Representative Office Records" and "Recognized Institutions Securities Staff Records" for public reference.

Preschool children participate in guided tours to learn about the design of Hong Kong banknotes.

HKMA staff introduce visitors to mosaic artworks made from Hong Kong coins depicting Victoria Harbour scenery.

# Community Engagement and Public Education

Since 1998, the HKMA has offered public educational talks, which have attracted over 68,000 participants to date. In 2024, we held online seminars with over 800 teachers and students from 41 secondary schools. Topics covered include the HKMA’s role, linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong banknotes, fraud prevention, deposit protection scheme, green finance, and opportunities in banking development.

We utilize various channels to connect and educate the public, reminding them to be savvy and responsible consumers of financial services. In 2024, over 67,000 citizens participated in our activities.

In response to the trend towards digital payments and green living, we promote via social media and radio broadcasts, encouraging the public to distribute electronic red packets during the Lunar New Year, and consider using physical "Welcoming Red Envelopes" for gift-giving.

Animated short videos are produced to encourage the distribution of electronic red packets.

# Fraud Prevention Song — "Link Mute Random Press"

To further strengthen fraud prevention, we launched a song co-sung by singer Mr. Raymond Yuen and the HKMA Deputy Chief Executive Mr. Ruan Guoheng, reminding citizens "Fake Link Mute, Believe It, Don’t Let People Trick You," and emphasizing the importance of protecting personal and credit card information. The multi-media promotional campaign has been well received and acclaimed internationally.

Mr. Ruan Guoheng (right) participates in performing the Fraud Prevention song.

Multimedia campaigns enhance public awareness of fraud prevention.

# "Cross-Border Wealth Management New Opportunities" TV Series

The HKMA collaborates with a local TV station to produce the "Cross-Border Wealth Management New Opportunities" TV series, helping the public better understand the opportunities and conveniences brought by the "Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Cross-border Wealth Management Connect" ("Cross-border Wealth Management"). Using five popular Hong Kong films’ “classic scenes,” the series explains the framework, investor eligibility, products provided by the "Northbound" and "Southbound" links, risk management, and precautions for cross-border investing, promoted via TV, digital, and social media platforms.

The series uses a humorous approach to introduce "Cross-Border Wealth Management."

# Hong Kong-wide Financial Literacy Contest

To enhance financial literacy among secondary students, the HKMA partners with several related organizations to host the "Hong Kong Financial Literacy Contest." Celebrating its tenth anniversary in 2024 with the theme "Future Financial Talents," the contest aims to introduce students early to innovations, Fintech, artificial intelligence, and future trends, while promoting principles of sustainable development and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations.

The first part is an online quiz testing students’ financial knowledge and understanding of hot financial topics. In 2024, 32,000 participants from 290 schools took part, setting a new record. Since 2015, about 125,000 entries from 440 schools have been recorded in the online quiz segment. The second part, the "Youth Financial Talent Program," pairs students with mentors in various financial sectors to prepare them for the "Design Thinking Challenge." In 2024, this part was enhanced with a "Greater Bay Area Invitational," encouraging interaction among students from Guangdong, Hong Kong, and Macao.

Mr. Chen Weimin, Vice President, delivers a welcoming speech at the final round of the contest and encourages participants.

# Educational Board Games

In 2023, the HKMA launched its first financial education board game, "Smart Finance 321," and continued to promote it in 2024. The game aims to familiarize more people with this original educational tool, enabling primary students to learn different payment methods, basic financial concepts, Fintech, and cybersecurity through simulated scenarios.

In the community, we set up booths at the "Hong Kong Book Fair 2024," and organized workshops during Christmas and Lunar New Year festivals. Parent-child workshops are also held at HKMA offices to promote financial literacy. In addition, we arrange school visits for students to try the game and conduct training workshops to encourage secondary school teachers to incorporate the game into the new "Civic, Economics, and Society" curriculum module. Furthermore, we continue to support the Investor and Financial Education Council in enhancing Hong Kong citizens’ financial literacy and capabilities. We will explore further collaboration with various stakeholders to improve community engagement.

To maintain high transparency, the HKMA adopts international financial disclosure standards applicable to central banks, including Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards and special data release standards from the IMF.
